Korean Christian Federation (KCF)


KCF in the 2010s gradually lost its status as the representative united organization of Korean Protestantism, entering a path of rapid decline due to politicization, heretical issues, and internal corruption. During this period, the KCF became both a symbol of conservative religious circles and a harbinger of their downfall, profoundly impacting public trust in Korean churches and the direction of the unity movement.

In the early 2010s, the KCF still functioned as the largest united organization representing approximately 12 million believers. Its founding background was a conservative reaction against the progressive-leaning National Council of Churches in Korea (NCCK). When the NCCK emphasized North-South reconciliation and unification while criticizing anti-communist ideology, conservative religious leaders who felt threatened by this united around major denominations under the banner of defending national security and conservative church values, resulting in the establishment of the KCF. However, contrary to its founding ideals, the KCF gradually became politicized by actively supporting specific regimes and ideologies, while internally developing an entrenched structure of vested interests.

The 2011 allegations of vote-buying involving Pastor Gil Ja-yeon exploded the KCF's internal crisis. This process revealed a complex web of fraudulent activities surrounding the representative chairmanship, decisions to lift heretical designations, and power monopolization by specific individuals. Major denominations including Presbyterian Church in Korea (Tonghap), Hapdong, Kosin, and Baekseok successively withdrew, and in 2012, the establishment of a separate united body, the Korea Church Coalition (KCC), effectively collapsed the KCF's representativeness. From this point, the KCF was reduced to an organization centered on minor denominations, with analyses suggesting that only about 3% of all Protestants remained.

Amid this decline, the KCF walked an increasingly politicized path. When Pastor Jeon Kwang-hoon of Sarang Jeil Church was elected as representative chairman in 2019, the KCF moved toward becoming a center of far-right political activities. He pushed through the lifting of heretical designations for Pastor Byeon Seung-woo, who had been defined as heretical, and appointed him as co-chairman of the KCF, thereby dismantling existing principles for dealing with heresy. Simultaneously, he declared solidarity with the Liberty Korea Party, expressed support for general elections, and issued a statement calling for President Moon Jae-in's resignation. Throughout this process, the KCF maintained an extreme anti-government stance, claiming that "Juche ideology believers had occupied the Blue House".

Under Jeon Kwang-hoon's leadership, the KCF directly violated government quarantine guidelines during the COVID-19 pandemic by forcing through Gwanghwamun rallies, resulting in cluster infections. This caused fatal damage to the credibility of not only the KCF but Korean churches as a whole. Pastor Jeon himself was infected, and some conservative YouTubers and KCF figures spread COVID-19 conspiracy theories, further undermining public trust.

Backlash arose from Korean churches broadly. Organizations such as the Christian Ethics Movement, the Church Coalition, and the Healthy Small Church Alliance officially declared disconnection by defining the KCF as "an organization that does not represent Korean churches." Major denominations had already withdrawn from the KCF or suspended activities, with even the Campus Crusade for Christ and Kihaseong departing. The KCF had essentially fallen from being a truly representative united organization to becoming an activity space for some far-right political forces and heretical groups.

By the late 2010s, the KCF could no longer realize its founding ideals—the vision of Protestant unity and contribution to social public good. Blind support for conservative ideology, collusion with megachurches, acceptance of heretical figures, and power-centered operations undermined religious conscience and morality, and by blurring the boundaries between religion and politics, seriously damaged the church's public standing. Christian networks demanding church reform had been calling for the KCF's dissolution since 2011, defining it as "an organization that has completed its historical lifespan." The subsequent movement toward new united organizations like the Korea Church Total Federation was a response and purification flow made against this background.

In conclusion, the KCF from 2010-2020 became a symbolic case comprehensively demonstrating the politicization, corruption, and heretical problems of Korean conservative Protestantism, leaving massive repercussions of declining social trust in Korean churches as a whole and the reorganization of the unity movement.


Korean Church Alliance (KCA)


During the 2010s, Korean Protestantism encountered a decisive turning point marked by the intersection of fragmentation and reorganization within its ecumenical movements. The Korea Christian Council (KCC), previously the largest conservative coalition, lost credibility within ecclesiastical circles due to controversies over heresy rehabilitations, money-driven elections, and political bias, resulting in the withdrawal of major denominations. Amid this crisis, the Korea Church Federation (KCF) was established in 2011, positioning itself as an alternative to the KCC. However, it remained a limited coalition centered on medium-sized denominations, leaving Korean Protestantism with a representational vacuum.

During this period of division, efforts emerged to form a new coalition centered on denominational leaders, culminating in the official launch of the Korea Church Alliance (KCA) in 2017. The participation of major denominations—including the Presbyterian Church in Korea (Hapdong and Tonghap), the Korean Methodist Church, and the Assemblies of God in Korea—in a single official coalition for the first time represented an unprecedented event in Korean church history. The KCA sought to overcome the problems of previous ecumenical movements by emphasizing denomination-centered decision-making structures, transparent administrative operations, and political neutrality.

One of the KCA's most distinctive characteristics was its capacity for coordinated responses to social issues. Particularly in 2020, amid the COVID-19 pandemic, the KCA collaborated with individual denominations to establish quarantine guidelines and encouraged the transition to non-contact worship services, cooperating with government policies. However, when collective infections occurred in some churches and distrust toward churches escalated, the organization also issued statements criticizing government measures as political actions that unfairly scapegoated churches.

Another significant development during this period involved the infection spread originating from Shincheonji's Daegu church and Pastor Jeon Kwang-hoon's political rallies. These incidents became catalysts for sweeping societal criticism of "Protestantism as a whole," prompting the KCA to reaffirm its position on churches' political neutrality and social responsibility. Prior to the 2020 general elections, the organization emphasized that "church-level support for specific candidates should be avoided" and issued official statements urging pastors to refrain from political remarks. Notably, in 2025, the KCA clearly delineated its boundaries with extremist political forces by declaring its principle of "supporting neither the far-right nor the far-left".

The KCA also devoted efforts to traditional church service activities, including social service, North Korea assistance, and disaster relief. During the 2018 PyeongChang Winter Olympics and the 2024 Gangwon Winter Youth Olympics, the organization deployed volunteers and organized welcoming activities while conveying messages of Korean Peninsula peace and unification. Additionally, the KCA clarified Christian positions on major social issues such as anti-discrimination laws, abortion law revisions, and private school law amendments through policy proposals and critical statements based on biblical values. Simultaneously, however, Korean churches were plagued by recurring scandals including the Myungsung Church succession controversy, clergy sexual crimes, and church financial corruption. Consequently, according to a public opinion survey released in 2020, only 31.8% of respondents indicated they "trust Korean churches." In this context, while the KCA focused on restoring church credibility and preventing next-generation departure, it failed to overcome structural limitations of overall membership decline and weakened social influence. 

In conclusion, during 2010–2020, the KCA endeavored to restore representational legitimacy through new denomination-centered ecumenical movements, emphasizing political neutrality and social responsibility while positioning itself as a unifying force for divided church coalitions. However, facing enormous challenges including rapidly changing social environments, recurring internal ethical problems, and plummeting trust in an increasingly secularized society, these efforts represented a turning point but failed to provide a complete solution.


Table 1. Korean Church Unity


| Category | CCK (1989~) | CEK (2011~) | UCCK (2017~) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Background of Establishment | Conservative alliance, check against NCCK | Reaction to CCK's heresy clearance and money politics | Church leader–centered reform of unity movement |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Representative Denominations | Major large denominations (before withdrawal) | Some medium-sized denominations | Large denominations like Hapdong, Tonghap, Methodist, AG (Yoido) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Activities (2010–2020) | Political entanglement, weakened representation, fragmentation | Alternative to CCK, limited influence | Joint response to social issues, emphasis on political neutrality and unity legitimacy |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Social Impact | Loss of representation, relegated to small consultative body | Mid-level organization with limited outreach | Secured representation, attempted to restore public trust |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |


Catholic Committee for Justice and Peace (CCJP) of Korea


In 2010, the CCJP raised serious concerns about ecological destruction regarding the Four Major Rivers Project, which was being forcibly implemented under government leadership at the time and hosted the seminar "Christian Response to the Four Major Rivers Project". This was an attempt to concretize the Church's ecological theological position that went beyond simple policy opposition, arguing that humanity must transcend anthropocentric development paradigms. The following year in 2011, the CCJP officially issued a statement opposing the construction of the naval base in Gangjeong Village, Jeju, urging society to prioritize the values of peace and life. The CCJP visited the Gangjeong Village site with residents and celebrated Mass, encompassing even forms of physical solidarity, delivering a theological message that national security logic should not overwhelm community survival rights. In 2013, they actively voiced concerns about the conflict surrounding the construction of transmission towers in Miryang. The conflict that arose during the process of erecting massive transmission towers on land that elderly residents considered their livelihood base and life space was not merely a regional dispute but an event that revealed the essential dilemma between development and survival, economy and dignity that Korean society as a whole faced. The CCJP expressed its position on this issue from a perspective centered on life and solidarity, accepting residents' suffering as the Church's pain through field Masses and messages of comfort.

Beyond these environmental and development-related issues, the CCJP devoted itself to activities for the rights of the socially vulnerable and those who suffer. Even after the Yongsan tragedy (2009), it continued to comfort bereaved families and served as a channel to convey their demands to society, leading efforts to protect workers' rights through solidarity Masses for laid-off Ssangyong Motors workers and visits to protest sites. Particularly during the Sewol ferry disaster in 2014, it participated in declarations calling for truth clarification and was remembered as a representative religious institution that stood in solidarity with victims' families. The CCJP continuously celebrated memorial services and commemorative Masses for the victims, demonstrating that the Church is a "community that suffers together and remembers."

The CCJP also raised its voice in the area of women's rights. In 2011, it showed solidarity with the 1000th Wednesday demonstration calling for resolution of the Japanese military comfort women issue, and after the announcement of the Korea-Japan government agreement on comfort women in 2016, it issued a strongly critical statement arguing that victim-centered resolution principles had been ignored. Simultaneously, the CCJP systematically conducted social doctrine education for consciousness growth within the Church community. It annually commemorated Social Doctrine Week by hosting various seminars, forums, and lectures, and through the "Social Doctrine School," it opened educational venues where laypeople, youth, and religious could reflect together on faith and social reality. During election periods, it sent questionnaires to major political parties asking about their positions on policies related to life, peace, labor, environment, and social welfare that the Church considered important, and by publicizing the results, it guided believers to participate as voters with social responsibility.

At the regional level, each diocesan CCJP responded to local issues and developed independent activities. For example, the Daejeon Diocese established a Social Doctrine School, presided over Life and Peace Masses, participated in anti-nuclear movements and the establishment of forced labor statues, and strengthened youth CCJP activities by operating programs such as peace pilgrimages and youth social doctrine training.

Thus, from 2010 to 2020, the Catholic Committee for Justice and Peace consistently acted for solidarity with those who suffer, realization of social justice, and protection of human dignity, and these activities were not merely social movements but expressions of faith and a journey to realize the Church's prophetic mission. The CCJP's voice was the Church's conscience responding to the pain of the times, and its existence became a reference point that constantly made Korean society reflect on religion's public nature and social responsibility.


Christian Ethics Movement of Korea (CEMK)


During this period, the Korean church faced serious social distrust due to internal issues such as church succession practices, financial opacity, and ethical lapses by some leaders, as well as external challenges including politicization controversies and the pandemic situation. Within this crisis context, CEMK played a central role in promoting church self-reflection and ethical reform.

One of the most representative activities was the "Public Trust Survey of Korean Churches." This survey, conducted regularly since 2008, continued in 2010, 2013, 2017, and 2020, quantitatively demonstrating the sustained decline in society's trust toward Protestant churches. According to the 2013 survey, Protestant churches had a trust rating of 19.4%, significantly lower than Buddhism (32.8%) or Catholicism (30.3%). This result evidenced that Christianity's image in Korean society was being perceived more in terms of hypocrisy, authoritarianism, and political bias rather than trustworthiness. Based on this sense of crisis, CEMK organized various practical campaigns. Under the banner of the "Good Society Movement," they launched initiatives including youth debt relief campaigns, credit counselor training, fair election movements, and ethical investment campaigns. Particularly, concrete practices such as debt counseling for young people, financial education, and loan conversion support demonstrated that CEMK was providing actual assistance beyond mere declarative movements. Following the Constitutional Court's ruling on abortion laws, they actively participated in subsequent legislation and social discussions, and through the "Education with Rest" campaign, they advocated for improved rest and educational environments for both teachers and students.

Communication with young people was also a major focus. Programs such as the "Self-Break Project," "Church Youth Project," and "Youth Prayer" were designed to bridge the gap between young people's sense of alienation within churches, their faith concerns, and their social responsibility consciousness. Creating a church culture where youth could take initiative and publishing regular prayer texts that combined social practice with faith represented experiments in capturing the voices of the younger generation that Korean churches had ignored throughout the 2010s.

CEMK also publicized social issues related to Christian ethics through "Right Values Seminars" and encouraged daily practices responding to environmental problems like fine dust and climate crisis through the "Voluntary Inconvenience Movement." Workshops on "Making Air Purifiers," campaigns for "Not Spreading Fake News," "Using Respectful Language," and "Caring for Emotional Laborers" were attempts to connect faith with ethical attitudes in daily life. These practices emerged from concerns about Korean churches retreating into realms of faith disconnected from ethics, presenting an alternative of ethical faith.

Critical efforts toward structural church problems and improvement initiatives were also strongly developed. Regarding anti-church succession movements, CEMK actively intervened through commentaries, forums, cultural festivals, press conferences, and petition drives. In the "Church Financial Health Movement," they continued education on comprehensive income tax for pastors and strengthening financial transparency. This series of activities indicated that their focus extended beyond merely criticizing phenomena to actually changing internal church systems.

When the COVID-19 pandemic struck Korean society in 2020, CEMK strongly criticized cluster infections at some churches that ignored quarantine rules and the politicized statements and actions of Christian leaders, issuing statements demanding the restoration of churches' public character and ethics. During this period, with cluster infections originating from Shincheonji and political rallies led by Pastor Jeon Kwang-hoon, Korean churches found themselves at the center of social condemnation, and CEMK's 2020 opinion survey revealed the shocking result that four out of five citizens did not trust churches. In this crisis phase, CEMK presented a direction that Korean churches should communicate with society, engage in self-purification, and restore trust through ethical practice. Simultaneously, through activities discovering and recognizing churches working with local communities, and through solidarity with various civil society organizations, they contributed to realizing universal values such as human rights, environment, peace, and minority rights. These activities, linked with CEMK's online content such as "Good Tree," also contributed to forming public discourse connecting faith and life.

In summary, from 2010 to 2020, CEMK diagnosed the ethical condition of crisis-stricken Korean churches, presented alternatives through concrete practices, and performed an important mediating role for restoring trust between churches and society. Nevertheless, structural problems within churches and social distrust still remain deeply rooted, and the task of restoring ethics and public character that CEMK presented continues to be an ongoing challenge.


Association of Gospel Attorneys & Lawyers (AGAL)


This was established in July 2020 to legally defend evangelical values, freedom of faith, and religious liberty. The founding conference was held at the Sheraton Palace Hotel in Seoul, with prominent Christian legal professionals including attorney Jeon Yong-tae, former National Intelligence Service Director Kim Seung-gyu, and former Constitutional Court Justices Ahn Chang-ho and Cho Dae-hyeon serving as co-representatives, publicly declaring the formation of a conservative Christian legal network.

AGAL's core activities are concentrated on blocking the enactment of comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation (anti-discrimination law). The organization strongly opposes such legislation, arguing that it would directly conflict with Christian values by imposing state protection obligations regarding issues like homosexuality, gender transition, and abortion, while legally constraining the expression of faith and conscience. In particular, they have focused on actively informing the general public and church communities about the content of such bills through various channels including "academic conferences to reveal the reality of anti-discrimination law," "production of legal reference materials," "distribution of church summary guides," "petition drives and statement releases."

As a legal organization, AGAL has also provided legal consultation and litigation support to churches and civic organizations. They offer legal services representing Christian positions in cases related to anti-discrimination law or gender issues, while building practical response capabilities. Representative examples include providing legal consultation and connecting attorneys when churches or pastors criticizing anti-discrimination law face legal action, and operating support systems backing constitutional appeals or administrative lawsuits.

In the education and research sector, AGAL has operated continuous education programs for Christian legal professionals such as the "Understanding Anti-Discrimination Law Academy," while simultaneously attempting to systematize evangelical interpretations of constitutional, human rights, and freedom concepts. An important characteristic here is their presentation of an evangelical human rights perspective distinct from existing secular human rights discourse through concepts like "natural rights," "faith-based legal theory," and "Christian ethics and public order".

AGAL has also actively participated in legislative and political monitoring activities. They have worked to reflect the Christian community's position in the legislative and amendment process through analyzing provisions of anti-discrimination bills or basic human rights bills introduced in the National Assembly, delivering opinion papers to legislators' offices, and issuing statements. In 2022 and 2023, AGAL issued strong opposition statements regarding multiple anti-discrimination law-related bills, defining them as "anti-biblical attempts that shake the foundation of the rule of law".

In 2024, they criticized the Lausanne Seoul Congress declaration for remaining silent on anti-discrimination law, characterizing this as a betrayal of the evangelical position. AGAL expressed concern that this declaration could be exploited by pro-anti-discrimination law forces and declared their intention to continue the movement to block such legislation alongside evangelicals worldwide. In October of the same year, AGAL publicly labeled the Christian Ethics Movement of Korea (CEMK) as "apostate forces" and demanded a retraction statement after CEMK took a favorable stance toward anti-discrimination law at a "Korean Church United Worship Service," triggering conflicts within the Korean church community.

Through these activities, AGAL serves as a focal point in conservative church legislative response strategies based on a network of over 200 Christian legal professionals, law professors, and pastors, and is evaluated as an organization that has had practical influence on the repeated introduction and withdrawal process of anti-discrimination legislation. Furthermore, the controversies they have led have served as a catalyst for promoting extensive pro and con discourse about anti-discrimination law not only within churches but across the religious community, civil society, and political circles at large.


Korean Women’s Christian Organizations


In the 2010s, Korean women's Christian organizations created a new wave of activism, advocating for "gender equality" and "justice" at the intersection of church and society. When the #MeToo movement that shook society in 2018 spread into churches, organizations like the Korean Christian Women's Movement Coalition, the Association of Women Theologians, and the Christian Women's Counseling Center systematically launched victim testimony rallies, forums, legal consultations, and the "Holy Anger" campaign. These groups established various channels to ensure that victims of sexual violence within churches could voice their experiences, receive safe counseling, and access legal and emotional support.

While sexual violence cases within churches during this period encountered walls of concealment and minimization, women's organizations emphasized victim-centered solidarity and healing. For example, the Christian Anti-Sexual Violence Center, established in 2018, handled over 40 cases of sexual violence counseling and took the lead in providing practical support through survivor speaking events, book concerts, and the production of the church sexual violence response guidebook "MeToo ChurchToo WithYou". Organizations like the Methodist Women's Leadership Development Institute formed church sexual violence task force teams to create response manuals and expanded the "With You" movement for victims.

The Association of Women Theologians deepened the popularization of feminist theology and social solidarity through initiatives such as the "Speaking of Women's Theology and Feminism" academy, "Church, Politics, and Women" forums, and 40th anniversary commemoration events. They consistently held theological seminars that criticized the limitations of male-centered theology while exploring gender-equal church models and alternative worship practices. The National Association of Women Ministers of the Presbyterian Church in the Republic of Korea led efforts to expand women's leadership and achieve equality within churches through annual assemblies, educational conferences, publication of newsletters on women's ministry and life ministry, solidarity activities for gender equality, and collaboration with the Korean Council for Justice and Remembrance.

In 2019, groups like the Women's Committee of Bible Korea and the Women Ministers' Association of the Presbyterian Church in the Republic of Korea held theological seminars on "Scripture and Women's Liberation" and experimented with alternative churches and worship practices. This movement also expanded into new media, where young women theologians shared biblical interpretation, sermons, and church reform discussions with the public through YouTube and blogs, creating a new generational current.

Throughout 2010-2020, women's Christian organizations maintained multilayered and practical movements including rallies, campaigns, institutional reforms, theological discussions, and victim support aimed at eradicating sexual violence within churches and achieving gender equality. Their activities posed the themes of "justice and equality" to Korean churches and society, driving waves of change.

Multicultural and Immigrant Mission Movement


Entering the 2010s, Korean society gradually normalized the presence of multiculturalism and immigrants. As of 2019, the immigrant population had already exceeded 2.22 million, accounting for 4.3% of the total population, with immigrants of diverse backgrounds—including migrant workers, marriage migrant women, foreign students, Koryo-saram (ethnic Koreans from former Soviet states), and North Korean defectors—beginning to settle nationwide¹. Amid these changes, Korean churches and private missionary organizations began to recognize new missionary callings and launched various ministries for immigrants.

In the early 2010s, the 'Naseum Community' in Seoul's Gwangjin District and 'Global Village Love Sharing' in Guro District established themselves as representative private institutions for immigrant mission. Beyond simple gospel evangelization, they operated diverse welfare and educational programs including foreign worship services, free medical clinics, shelters, Korean language education, multicultural schools, Mongolian schools, and daycare centers. Global Village Love Sharing, in particular, which originated from migrant worker human rights movements in the 1990s, had expanded to such a scale by the 2010s that it transferred 52 facilities to nearby churches free of charge, broadening its ministry to include baby boxes, group homes, multicultural alternative schools, foreigner-exclusive worker clinics, and immigrant broadcasting stations.

In provincial areas, the Daejeon Comprehensive Welfare Center for Foreign Immigrants attempted a social enterprise model by operating the multicultural restaurant 'I'm Asia' to create employment opportunities for immigrant women. Cheonan Sky Central Church was commissioned by the government to operate a Foreign Worker Support Center and Multicultural Family Support Center, working to improve immigrant settlement and welfare through counseling, education, free medical care, and cultural events. Ansan Onnuri Church established an 'M Center' in a foreign-concentrated area, providing worship services for 14 national communities, shelters, one-on-one discipleship, free medical care, and education. They implemented a missionary strategy of raising local ministry workers so immigrants could lead their own faith communities and be 'reverse-sent' to their home countries.

Mission to North Korean defectors (saeteomin) was also noteworthy. Seoul's Great Commission United Mission established social enterprises (box factories, curtain factories, cafes, etc.) to support defectors' self-reliance and settlement, operating talent development programs so they could grow as future North Korean church leaders. Conversely, Hari Church in Wanju, North Jeolla Province attempted immigrant women's mission in rural areas but discontinued due to lack of professional staff, financial difficulties, and overlap with local community welfare facilities.

In the late 2010s, existing missionary organizations that had depended on donations experienced COVID-19 and financial crises, acutely recognizing the need for self-reliance. Consequently, 'Business as Mission' emerged as an alternative. Representative examples include the following organizations:

Turtle Books: Developed art education content supplied to domestic and international kindergartens, international schools, and nursing homes, while operating art classes for multicultural family children. They pursued self-reliance by crossing boundaries between profit and non-profit sectors.

Café Binuvel: Thai returnee immigrants operated cafes and second-hand clothing outlets locally, simultaneously pursuing economic self-reliance and faith communities. This model demonstrates the combination of returnee immigrant 'reverse mission' and 'business mission.

Koryo-saram Village Cooperative: The Koryo-saram village in Gwangju Metropolitan City worked toward job creation, economic self-reliance, and restoration of Koryo-saram history and culture through a cooperative comprising about 30 stores with annual sales of 5 billion won.

Multicultural International School: An alternative school in Pocheon provided academic certification and Korean social adaptation education for multicultural children who entered Korea mid-education, playing a key role in multicultural social integration.

These organizations applied corporate management principles—differentiation strategies, cost advantage strategies, and focus strategies—to missionary fields, seeking sustainable mission through business model innovation.

During this period, multicultural and immigrant mission created new paradigms of 'integration of welfare and gospel,' 'immigrant agency and reverse mission,' and 'self-reliance through business models.' However, structural limitations such as dependence on government support, inter-institutional competition, and difficulties in financial self-reliance still remain¹².

For Korean churches moving forward, systematic support at denominational levels, social solidarity, professional enhancement, and development of sustainable business models will become increasingly important.


Me Too Movement and With You Theology


Since 2018, Korean churches have confronted a critical challenge: responding to sexual violence allegations and the church community's handling of these cases, particularly in conjunction with the broader #MeToo movement that swept across society. Women theologians and Christian women's movement organizations, in particular, began advocating for the necessity of 'WithYou (#WithYou)' theology that goes beyond simple victim statements to actively listen to and stand in solidarity with victims within the church. WithYou theology represented an alternative theological movement that demanded profound transformation extending from church structures and theological discourse to the very forms of ritual and worship, transcending mere victim support or pastoral care.

Lee Eun-sun explores the possibilities of WithYou theology within the heritage of Korean traditional thought and theology. For instance, by reinterpreting Joseph in Matthew's Gospel as a "righteous person" who stands with the victim Mary, she argues that WithYou theology demands ethical participation where the community takes collective responsibility rather than remaining silent or evasive beside victims. Furthermore, this WithYou attitude suggests a directional shift from 'hiding or concealing' women's sexuality and bodies to 'respecting and purifying' them. Lee Eun-sun views this theological transformation not merely as a matter of individual ethics but as a comprehensive project to reconstruct the entire paradigm of the church's ritual forms, worship structures, and biblical interpretation. She particularly draws attention to the "Hang-a-seol-wi (恒娥設位)" tradition advocated by Choi Si-hyeong (Haewol) of Donghak. This represented a method whereby women themselves performed rituals for their own sake, sanctifying their own bodies and histories, recognizing that the object of ritual was not the spirits of others but 'the life of myself and the universe breathing here and now'. The spirit of this Hang-a-seol-wi tradition aligns with the central philosophy of WithYou theology, which calls for transforming the direction of sexual ethics and liturgy within the church toward victim-centered awareness and communal practice, while critiquing Western patriarchal theological order. Moreover, Lee Eun-sun emphasizes that WithYou theology should not remain confined to the dimensions of sexual violence reporting and solidarity but must expand into a theological enlightenment movement that simultaneously targets the structural problems of both 'prostitution' and 'sexual violence'.

Given that deep-rooted misogyny and distorted understanding of sexuality in Korean society have penetrated even into religious institutions, she argues that comprehensive reform must accompany the reestablishment of all aspects of sexuality and the body, childbirth and care, education and communal life at the level of church ethics and institutions. In this regard, WithYou theology aims not merely to restore women's 'victimization' but to reorganize both church and society on the foundation of life ethics that respects human bodies, sexuality, and life itself.

Through this contemporary reinterpretation of traditional practices, Lee Eun-sun presents three directions that WithYou theology should pursue:

Recovering the nobility of sexuality and introducing symbolic worship and ritual forms that purify bodily existence

Restructuring theology and worship structures centered on victims and the vulnerable

Practicing communal awareness and ethical action regarding the structural conditions that generate sexual violence

She advocates that WithYou theology should become an integrative resistance theology and practical theology that merges Korean traditional thought with Christian theology, encompassing everything from Pestalozzi's communal reform education to the Donghak tradition of self-ritual.


Increase of Cannan People

From the 2010s to the early 2020s, a new faith group called "Canaan People" rapidly increased within Korean Christianity. These are believers who believe in Jesus but do not attend church, maintaining their faith while distancing themselves from institutional churches. This phenomenon goes beyond simple church attendance decline and connects to structural changes facing Korean society and churches, generational value conflicts, and broader societal secularization trends.

Multiple factors contributed to the background of the Canaan Saints phenomenon. Since the 2000s, various irregularities within Korean churches have been exposed, including pastoral misconduct, church financial problems, and materialistic tendencies centered on megachurches, leading to a significant decline in trust. Many believers felt that churches had lost their original identity as spiritual communities and developed skepticism toward churches. The younger generation, in particular, began to reject hierarchical and exclusive church structures. Millennials pursued "autonomous faith" and showed a clear tendency to continue their faith life without belonging to a church. In fact, 44% of Christian youth in their twenties answered that they have "no church to attend," showing the spread of attitudes that prioritize personal spirituality.

Social environment also accelerated this phenomenon. The 2015 Population and Housing Census showed that 56.1% identified as non-religious, demonstrating weakening religious affiliation. After 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted the routine of in-person worship and normalized online worship and non-contact faith practices. This further weakened the meaning of church attendance and accelerated the individualization of faith.


Table 2. Increase in Canaan Saints 

| Year | Percentage of “Nones” | Major Trigger Factors |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 2012 | 11% | Church conflicts, frequent ethical issues among pastors |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 2017 | 23.3% | Backlash against the excessive culture of megachurches |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 2023 | 29% | Fixation on online worship and acceleration of church disaffiliation |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 2025 | 31% | Expansion of individualized faith, especially among youth |
| --- | --- | --- |


The biggest reasons Canaan Saints left churches were "not wanting to be bound by church" (31%), "distrust of pastoral image" (14.4%), and "exclusivity of church members" (11.2%). In a 2023 survey, "COVID-19 impact" emerged as the second major cause. This phenomenon is actively studied in domestic and international academic journals. A 2019 study titled "Research on Effective Evangelism Strategies According to Church Departure Characteristics of Canaan Saints" defined Canaan Saints as a "Christian-non-religious boundary group" and emphasized the need for new evangelism strategies. A 2022 paper on "Millennial Generation Canaan Saints Phenomenon in Their 20s and 30s" analyzed how young people's pursuit of self-determination leads to church departure. Comparative studies with the UK pointed out that Korea's Canaan Saints phenomenon stems from "internal secularization" caused by the collapse of internal church authority, while the UK experiences "external secularization" due to social structural changes. English journals explain through the concept of "Believing Without Belonging" how the phenomenon of rejecting institutional religion while maintaining personal spirituality appears similarly to Korea.

Thus, the increase in Canaan Saints represents not merely a decline in church attendance but a fundamental shift in religious practice methods. Going forward, churches will need new response strategies including relationship-centered small group ministry, building digital spirituality communities, and developing participatory worship programs targeting the 2030 generation. The prevailing forecast is that without structural reform of churches, this phenomenon will spread further.

section: Key theological, doctrinal, or ecclesiastic issues in this decade, if any
text_en:
Conservative-Progressive Clashes During the Park Geun-hye Impeachment Crisis


The impeachment crisis of President Park Geun-hye from 2016 to 2017 was far more than a mere political event. This incident served as a catalyst that intensified the ideological and theological divisions between conservatives and progressives that had been deeply embedded within Korean Protestantism, creating significant ripple effects on the Korean church's political role, faith identity, and social credibility.

Historical Background

Korean Protestantism developed under the unique historical conditions of colonial rule, war, and the Cold War. During the Japanese colonial period, it aligned with the nationalist movement, and after liberation, it was positioned as a force opposing communism, becoming closely tied to American-centered liberal democracy and anti-communism. Starting in the 1950s, pastors and believers who fled from the North shared a collective trauma regarding communism, which solidified into the formula of 'anti-communism = faith.' Consequently, conservative Christianity embraced nationalism, authoritarianism, anti-communism, and pro-Americanism as if they were sacred values. In contrast, progressive Christianity that emerged after the 1970s, influenced by Minjung theology and liberation theology, formed a movement that emphasized human liberation, justice, and peace.

Park Geun-hye, Choi Soon-sil, and the Shock of Pseudo-Religion

In 2016, public outrage erupted when it was revealed that President Park Geun-hye had entrusted state affairs to Choi Soon-sil, a shadowy power broker, and operated through manipulated speeches, personnel decisions, and policies. What made the shock even more devastating was the presence of Choi Soon-sil's father, Choi Tae-min. Although he had once served as a pastor, he led a pseudo-religious movement that blended Christianity with shamanism and revelatory faith, wielding influence through his close relationship with Park Geun-hye. He claimed to be "one who receives God's revelations" and called Park Geun-hye his "spiritual daughter". When these facts became known, the majority of citizens experienced the collapse of religious trust beyond mere political accountability regarding the president, which soon led to massive candlelight vigils.

Candlelight Vigils and Taegeukgi Rallies

The candlelight vigils from late 2016 to early 2017, in which millions of citizens participated, represented peaceful civic action demanding the restoration of democracy and the elimination of corruption. Progressive Christian organizations and believers actively participated, holding 'square worship services' and 'prayer meetings for national affairs,' presenting new forms where politics and faith converged. They emphasized that civic action for democracy was itself the practice of faith. However, in opposition to this, conservative Christian forces interpreted Park Geun-hye's impeachment as spiritual warfare and organized "Taegeukgi rallies." They came to Gwanghwamun carrying Korean flags, American flags, and crosses, shouting slogans like "Park Geun-hye is a leader established by God" and "The Moon Jae-in administration consists of communists." Most of these participants were elderly conservative Christians who rallied around ideological anxiety, North Korean nuclear threats, homosexuality issues, and anti-Islamic sentiment.

Jeon Kwang-hoon, the Korea Christian Council, and the Rise of Far-Right Christianity

During this period, the Korea Christian Council (KCC) became radicalized toward far-right politics with the emergence of Pastor Jeon Kwang-hoon. Jeon Kwang-hoon called the president a 'red' and demanded his resignation, proclaiming that "God will bring down Moon Jae-in" and "If Moon Jae-in becomes president, South Korea will be ruined." He equated the 'Kingdom of God' with 'liberal democracy,' spreading far-right Christian nationalist political theology. While his statements resonated with many Christians, multiple denominations classified his remarks as heretical or officially withdrew from the organization.

Internal Church Reactions and the Deepening of Polarization

Internal church reactions were divided into three main streams. First, some churches actively participated in Jeon Kwang-hoon's movement and Taegeukgi rallies, regarding the protection of conservative government as a 'duty of faith.' Second, progressive churches participated in candlelight vigils, presenting the path of public theology that emphasized justice and repentance. Third, the majority of churches remained silent or experienced internal divisions in the face of this extreme polarization, suffering from declining membership, youth exodus, and decreased credibility.


This division went beyond mere differences in political views, stemming from fundamental theological principles including biblical interpretation, ecclesiology, views of the state, and eschatology.

Literalist Theology vs. Contextual Theology

Conservative Christianity has traditionally emphasized biblical inerrancy and literal interpretation, strongly supporting heresy vigilance and moral order. In the 2010s, conservative pastors strengthened their eschatological worldview, making "spiritual warfare" against homosexuality, Islam, and pro-North Korean ideology central sermon topics. Based on Genesis 2:24's principle of "one man and one woman," they regarded opposition to same-sex marriage as a faith obligation. In contrast, progressive Christianity embraced historical criticism and liberation theology, emphasizing contextual understanding of the Bible. They emphasized solidarity with marginalized neighbors such as sexual minorities, immigrants, female pastors, and irregular workers, redefining the church's role in society. This interpretation was rooted in texts that explicitly mention 'justice and mercy,' such as the Book of Amos or Matthew 25.

Political Messianism vs. Prophetic Faith

The conservative camp understood the Park Geun-hye administration as 'authority established by God' and interpreted the impeachment crisis as "Satan's work." Pastor Jeon Kwang-hoon and the Korea Christian Council, in particular, defined Taegeukgi rallies as battlegrounds of spiritual warfare, claiming that "the Moon Jae-in administration consists of communists and must be expelled." This rhetoric, combined with the eschatological view of the state found in Isaiah and Daniel, led to interpreting Korean politics as 'spiritual combat.'

Conversely, progressive churches followed the tradition of prophetic faith, emphasizing criticism of unjust power. During the 2016-2017 candlelight vigils, over 1,000 Christians issued the 'Christian Declaration for the Realization of Justice' and proclaimed the 'mission of salt and light' through street worship services and prayer meetings. They warned that the moment religion embraces power, the Gospel of Jesus becomes corrupted.

Anti-Communist Trauma vs. Peaceful Unification Theology

The conservative camp theologically internalized memories of the Korean War and anti-communist ideology. They interpreted North Korea as the 'Antichrist' and attacked progressive churches' unification movement as "pro-North Korean theology." Particularly during the 2018 inter-Korean summit, some denominations issued statements saying, "do not be deceived by deceptive peace shows."

The progressive camp, centered on Isaiah 2:4's symbol of peace to "beat swords into plowshares," regarded unification and reconciliation as theological missions. They argued that viewing division as "God's order" was itself a distortion of faith.

Clash of Ecclesiology

Conservative churches understood the church as a "holy realm separated from the world" and perceived external demands for change as infringement upon faith. They regarded resistance to quarantine guidelines, sexual minority rights demands, and gender sensitivity education as matters of faith protection. The Sarang Jeil Church cluster infection incident was interpreted as a consequence of this worldview. Progressive churches, however, understood the church as a "public community that responds to the world's suffering" and actively engaged in mask sharing, emergency relief, and care ministry during COVID-19. They believed that when the church abandons social responsibility, the public nature of the Gospel fades.


Table 3. Comparison of Conservative and Progressive Theologies

| Category | Conservative Theology | Progressive Theology |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Biblical Interpretation | Biblical inerrancy, literal reading, emphasis on traditional doctrine | Historical criticism, contextual interpretation, social ethics and responsibility |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Core Values | Anti-communism, anti-LGBT, family-centered, emphasis on order and security | Human rights, peace, social justice, solidarity with the marginalized, diversity and inclusion |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Political Stance | Anti-North Korea, support for conservative parties, nationalism, pro-Taegeukgi rallies | Pro-peace/unification, pro-civil society, participation in Candlelight Vigils, criticism of power |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Social Engagement | Alignment with national power, anti-labor movements, religious exclusivism | Solidarity with the marginalized, labor/environment/gender/LGBT inclusion |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Ethics | Absolute moralism, traditional family ethics, separatist community | Ethics of responsibility (Bonhoeffer, Niebuhrian), inclusive community (Derrida, Trinitarian) |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Key Issues | Opposition to homosexuality, Islam, refugees, pro-authoritarian church order | Acceptance of LGBT, Muslims, refugees, social diversity, ecclesial democracy |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Representative Theology | ‘Faith = Patriotism’, ‘Anti-communism = Faith’, ‘Obedience = God’s Will’ | ‘Faith = Responsibility’, ‘Justice = Faith’, ‘Cross = Jesus’ Way’ |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Representative Incidents | Taegeukgi rallies post-impeachment, anti-mask protests during COVID-19 | Candlelight Vigils, human rights/peace movement, democratic ecclesiology |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Theological Roots | Fundamentalism, dispensationalism, trauma of Korean War, American revivalism | Liberation theology, Minjung theology, Feminist/postcolonial theology, Niebuhr, Derrida |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Social Evaluation | Authoritarianism, exclusion, alliance with political power | Advocacy for social justice, inclusion, empowerment of marginalized voices |
| --- | --- | --- |

section: Anti-Christian Leaders (including competitors from secularisms and other religions who argued or campaigned against Christianity)
Anti-Christian Organizations (including competing organizations of secularisms and other religions that campaigned against Christianity)
Anti-Christian Events/Movements (including competing events/movements against Christianity)
text_en:
In 2010s Korean society, the anti-Christian movement expanded beyond simple religious criticism into an organized and sustained socio-cultural movement. This phenomenon was triggered by the convergence of rapid internet proliferation, the popularity of anti-culture, and aggressive Protestant evangelism. The movement explosively spread through cyberspace using crude mockery and hate expressions such as 'gae-dok-gyo' (dog-Christianity), 'meok-sa' (eating pastor), and 'gae-jip' (dog house), representing a fundamentally different form of cultural resistance from past anti-Christian movements—one that was non-physical and language-centered.

The roots of the anti-Christian movement can be traced to the 1920s socialist religious eradication theory and anti-Christian discourse. However, the modern movement centered around cyberspace rather than print media, with ordinary citizen netizens as the primary actors rather than party officials or intellectuals. The 1999 Dangun statue vandalism incident served as a symbolic starting point, with Protestant exclusivity manifesting as destruction of traditional culture, sparking genuine social backlash. Subsequently, "carpet evangelism," street loudspeaker preaching, Buddha statue destruction, temple intrusions, and demands for worship in public institutions stimulated widespread social antipathy. The 2007 Afghanistan hostage crisis further strengthened anti-Christian discourse. This incident, where a Protestant missionary team was kidnapped in a Muslim region resulting in fatalities, imprinted the dangers and irresponsibility of "aggressive overseas missions" across Korean society, providing the foundation for anti-Christian claims that "Christian evangelism is violence". During the same period, succession controversies, sexual scandals, and financial corruption that erupted in megachurches such as Yoido Full Gospel Church, Sarang Church, and Myeongseong Church played a decisive role in solidifying the image of Christianity as a corrupt power group.

These criticisms spread through organized online communities. Representative sites such as 'Club Anti-Christianity,' 'Citizens' Movement Against Christianity (Ban-gi-ryun),' 'Anti-Bible,' and 'Anti-Jesus' boasted tens of thousands of members and conducted regular offline meetings, publishing, and legal petition campaigns. They criticized biblical violence, Jesus's historicity, and church authority structures, even filing petitions to designate the Bible as harmful literature.

The ideological foundation of this movement rested on two main pillars. First, cultural nationalism regarded Christianity as a remnant of Western imperialism and defined it as a destroyer of traditional culture and ethnic identity. This was related to opposition to Dangun statue removal, criticism of temple vandalism, and movements to reevaluate shamanism and traditional thought. Second, secular humanism viewed Christianity as an anti-rational, exclusive, and undemocratic religion, criticizing it based on standards of human rights and rationality. They particularly opposed creation science, attacks on evolution, bans on New Age music, and mandatory chapel attendance, targeting churches as symbols of anti-intellectualism.

The targets of such criticism can be generally categorized as follows: 1) Moral corruption of clergy and leadership (sexual scandals, embezzlement, succession),2) Exclusive behavior toward other religions and cultures (Dangun statue and Buddha statue vandalism), 3) Irrational responses to popular culture and science (creation science, music censorship), 4) Lack of consideration for the vulnerable (criticism of disabled people and sexual minorities), 5) Politicization and empowerment of churches (conservative political involvement), etc. Protestant responses were divided between conservative and progressive camps. The conservative camp formed a frame of "Christian eradication forces," focusing on training 'internet missionaries,' legal responses, and organized counterattacks. Conversely, the progressive camp accepted this as a social warning and mirror of reflection regarding corruption and incompetence within Christianity, moving toward emphasizing moral responsibility and social participation. Pastor Jang Seok-hyeon interpreted this as "God's rebuke sent to the church," urging church self-reform.

Thus, the anti-Christian movement of the 2010s was not simple Christian hatred, but a complex phenomenon where social structures and power, cultural identity, ethical issues, and rational beliefs intersected. This movement clearly revealed the crisis of trust and moral bankruptcy faced by Korean Protestantism, providing an opportunity that pressured churches to answer fundamental questions of ethical recovery, social responsibility, inclusive dialogue with other religions and traditional cultures, and rational faith recovery beyond simple 'counter-responses'.

section: Governmental Regulations on Religion and Legal Cases
text_en:
South Korea

Between 2010 and 2020, South Korea experienced significant government interventions in religious affairs, reflecting broader constitutional tensions around church-state separation, religious freedom, tax equity, human rights, and national security. This decade saw both collaboration and conflict between religious communities and the state as various legal and administrative measures generated controversy and reshaped the relationship between religion and public policy.

The Four Major Rivers Project and Religious Environmental Opposition (2010-2012)

The Four Major Rivers Restoration Project, launched under President Lee Myung-bak's administration, became one of the first major policies to provoke organized religious opposition during this period. The government presented this large-scale infrastructure initiative as necessary for flood prevention and water security through river dredging, dam construction, and waterway restructuring. Religious leaders, particularly from Catholic and Protestant progressive organizations, mounted strong resistance to the project. The Catholic Bishops' Committee for Justice and Peace and the National Council of Churches in Korea issued public statements condemning the project as environmentally destructive. These religious voices grounded their opposition in Christian theological frameworks, specifically eco-theology and biblical creation stewardship, arguing that the government prioritized economic development over environmental protection and divine creation principles. The religious opposition represented an early example of how theological concerns could mobilize organized resistance to government policy, establishing a precedent for faith-based activism on environmental issues.

Religious Leader Income Taxation Implementation (2013-2018)

The introduction of income taxation for religious leaders represented the most significant administrative reform affecting religious communities during this decade. Historically, South Korean pastors, monks, and priests had been exempt from income tax, a practice that faced increasing criticism as inequitable and constitutionally problematic. In 2015, following extended legislative debate, the National Assembly passed a revised Income Tax Act that classified religious leaders' income as taxable under either "other income" or "earned income" categories, with implementation beginning January 1, 2018. The government justified this reform under Article 38 of the Constitution, which establishes universal tax obligations for all citizens. Many Protestant leaders opposed the taxation policy, arguing it violated religious autonomy and breached the constitutional principle of church-state separation outlined in Article 20. To address these concerns, the government provided implementation flexibility, allowing religious figures to choose between two income reporting methods and exempting religious organizations from mandatory income withholding requirements. Despite these accommodations, opposition persisted, with some religious groups filing constitutional complaints challenging the policy.

Comprehensive Anti-Discrimination Legislation Debates (2007-2020)

The most sustained and contentious policy debate of the decade centered on comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation, particularly provisions addressing sexual orientation and gender identity discrimination. The National Human Rights Commission of Korea began advocating for such legislation in 2006, but implementation faced significant religious opposition. In 2007, when the Ministry of Justice attempted to conduct public hearings on draft legislation including sexual orientation as a protected category, major conservative Christian organizations launched intensive opposition campaigns. This mobilization resulted in the removal of sexual orientation protections from the proposed legislation. The issue resurfaced in 2020 when the progressive Justice Party introduced new comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation in the National Assembly. The bill aimed to prohibit discrimination across education, employment, and public services based on various characteristics including race, religion, gender, and sexual orientation. While the National Human Rights Commission supported the legislation, major Protestant denominations argued it would criminalize traditional Christian teaching on sexuality and restrict religious institutions' doctrinal autonomy. Legal scholars from Christian institutions characterized the legislation as potential "legislative overreach" that could compromise constitutional religious freedom guarantees.

Conscientious Objection Recognition and Alternative Service Establishment (2018)

A significant development in church-state relations occurred with the 2018 Constitutional Court decision recognizing conscientious objection rights for military service based on religious convictions. South Korea's mandatory conscription policy, maintained due to ongoing tensions with North Korea, had historically resulted in prison sentences for religious minorities, particularly Jehovah's Witnesses, who refused military service based on pacifist theological beliefs. The Constitutional Court ruled that imprisoning conscientious objectors violated constitutional rights to freedom of conscience and religion. The Court ordered the government to establish alternative civilian service options, which were subsequently implemented. This decision marked a significant shift in state treatment of religious minorities, demonstrating increased institutional respect for individual religious convictions even when they conflicted with national security policies.

The 2010-2020 period revealed the complex dynamics of implementing constitutional principles in a religiously diverse democracy. These policy developments demonstrated how religious freedom, church-state separation, and equal legal treatment, while clearly articulated in constitutional text, proved challenging to implement in practice. The decade's controversies forced both religious communities and government institutions to clarify their positions and justify their claims through legal and political processes. While these debates were often contentious, they represented genuine democratic engagement with competing visions of religious freedom and state authority. The period's legacy lies not in the complete resolution of church-state tensions, but in the development of more sophisticated mechanisms for managing such tensions in a pluralistic society. The outcomes varied: some issues were resolved through compromise, others through decisive policy implementation, and still others through creative solutions that balanced multiple legitimate interests. These experiences provide important precedents for South Korea's continuing evolution as a democracy, demonstrating that while religious freedom and secular governance can create tensions, they are not inherently incompatible when managed through strong institutions and principled leadership committed to both democratic values and human dignity.

| --- | --- | --- |

North Korea

From 2010 to 2020, North Korea's policies and incidents related to Christianity represent a historical record of an era where the inextinguishable vitality of faith coexisted with thorough surveillance, oppression, systematic persecution, and human rights violations. During this period, North Korea was ranked as the world's worst persecutor of Christians by the international Christian missionary organization Open Doors for 20 consecutive years, treating Christian faith itself as an act of regime subversion. According to North Korean authorities, Christianity was a tool of American imperialism's infiltration and a foreign element threatening the juche ideology and the Kim family's idolization system.

While North Korea's constitution nominally guarantees religious freedom, this remains merely a formal provision. In practice, only a minimal number of state-sponsored churches like Bongsu Church and Chilgol Church have been operated for propaganda purposes targeting foreigners. Religious activities among ordinary citizens are strictly prohibited, with severe punishments including forced labor, torture, and execution imposed upon detection. The Christian population within North Korea is estimated at approximately 400,000, with reports indicating that at least 50,000 to 70,000 of them are imprisoned in political prison camps.

In the latter half of the 2010s, North Korea further intensified its ideological and cultural control. The "Anti-Reactionary Thought and Culture Rejection Law" enacted in 2020 particularly defined the influx of external ideologies and religious activities as "anti-state acts". This law treats Bible possession, hymn singing, contact with South Korean missionary organizations, and underground church gatherings as serious crimes, extending surveillance targets to include youth, women, and children. Consequently, in 2017, twelve residents in North Hamgyong Province were arrested on charges of contact with South Korean Christian missionary organizations and transferred to political prison camps. Reports also exist of a 2019 incident where an underground church on the outskirts of Pyongyang was discovered, resulting in the public execution of five individuals. Additionally, in cases of North Korean defectors, their Christian faith status was intensively investigated when captured and repatriated from China. For instance, international human rights reports document a 2022 case where a resident in South Hwanghae Province was sentenced to 15 years after a Bible was discovered. Testimonies also exist of forcibly repatriated defectors who confessed their Christian faith during interrogation being placed in solitary confinement or even summarily executed.

North Korea's persecution of Christianity functioned not merely as suppression of religious freedom, but as part of a comprehensive ideological control and surveillance governance strategy for regime maintenance. Christians were classified as "hostile class" in the social stratification system, facing extreme discrimination in school, workplace, and residential selection, with believing families becoming surveillance targets across generations. Nevertheless, underground churches and faith communities did not completely disappear but continued to exist covertly, with some North Korean defector Christians bearing witness to the existence of faith communities within North Korea in the international community, keeping alive the spark of hope¹⁰.

While the international community and human rights organizations have continuously called for North Korea to guarantee religious freedom, North Korea has ignored or rejected these appeals as "hostile forces' interference in internal affairs." The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom (USCIRF) and the UN Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in North Korea (COI) have designated North Korea's religious persecution as "crimes against humanity," which remains an important human rights issue under international law.

COVID-19 Pandemic and Shincheonji Church Stigmatization

The COVID-19 cluster infection outbreak at Daegu's Shincheonji Church in February 2020 sent shockwaves through Korean society. A 61-year-old female congregant continued attending church events even after developing symptoms, leading to a dramatic surge in confirmed cases from 31 to 6,767 within just one week. Of these cases, 63.5% were linked to Shincheonji members. This incident turned Shincheonji congregants into targets for social ostracism. Some restaurants and cafes posted signs reading "Shincheonji Members Prohibited," while online communities leaked personal information of church members and subjected them to violent threats. One office worker was fired solely for being a Shincheonji member, and cases of congregants being physically assaulted by their own family members were reported. The fallout extended beyond Shincheonji, with anti-Protestant sentiment spreading throughout society, resulting in approximately 400,000 Protestant believers leaving their churches during 2020.

Large-Scale Rally Against LGBTQ Rights

On October 27, 2024, 1.1 million Christians (according to on-site estimates) gathered at Seoul's Gwanghwamun Square and Yeouido to hold rallies opposing same-sex marriage legalization and anti-discrimination law enactment. The rally proceeded under the banners of "family protection" and "defending Christian faith," with its political overtones strengthened by supportive video messages from Seoul Mayor Oh Se-hoon. Participants chanted slogans like "homosexuality is sin" and opposed the Seoul Queer Culture Festival's use of public spaces, forcing the festival to relocate. Rally organizers emphasized opposition to lowering the age requirement for gender reassignment surgery, claiming that "Western LGBTQ policies destroy families." Critics pointed out that this movement would likely lead to the spread of hatred and undermine the principle of separation between church and state.

Persecution of Christians in North Korea

The North Korean regime classifies Christians as members of the "hostile class," subjecting them to three-generation collective punishment. According to a 2024 report, cases have been confirmed of Christian families, including two-year-old children, receiving life sentences, with approximately 70,000 Christians imprisoned in labor camps. North Korean defector Kim testified that "if Christian faith is discovered in North Korea, immediate execution or the entire family being dragged to concentration camps follows." South Korean churches operate specialized educational facilities for defectors, such as the "School of Freedom," providing Bible education alongside social adaptation programs. As of 2018, South Korean Christian organizations continue supporting underground churches by smuggling Bibles into North Korea and producing radio broadcasts for secret believer networks.

Internal Church Conflicts: The Case of Pastor Jun Kwang-hoon

In January 2025, following the issuance of an arrest warrant for President Yoon Seok-yul, conservative Christian supporters stormed the Seoul Western District Court, injuring five police officers and damaging windows. Pastor Jun Kwang-hoon, identified as being behind this incident, claimed it was a "righteous struggle against the court's injustice." However, major denominations including the Korea Christian Council declared their break with him, stating that "violence cannot be justified in the name of faith." This incident starkly revealed the ideological rift between conservative and progressive Christian forces.

Unification Efforts: 2024 Inter-denominational United Worship

On October 27, 2024, 2.1 million Christians (1.1 million on-site, 1 million online) participated in an inter-denominational united worship service in downtown Seoul under the theme "Social Purification through Repentance and Revival". While this event explicitly opposed expanding LGBTQ rights, it simultaneously included a declaration that "churches should become mediators of reconciliation rather than causes of social division." Speakers from the UK and Germany warned Korean churches that "Western LGBTQ policies have led to family breakdown." Worship participants adopted a statement promising expanded support for the socially vulnerable and maintaining political neutrality.

With Asian-Pacific Countries

In the shifting dynamics of the Korean Peninsula, North Korea remained the world's most brutal persecutor of Christians. Throughout this period, Open Doors, an international Christian monitoring organization, consistently ranked North Korea as the worst country for religious persecution. According to testimonies from North Korean defectors and reports, imprisonment in political prison camps for faith-related reasons was routine, and entire families faced punishment simply for possessing a Bible. South Korean churches and missionary organizations continued their humanitarian aid to North Korean residents and covert missionary work—this wasn't mere relief efforts, but a response to the conscience and calling of believers.

Our diplomatic relationship with China was economically tight-knit, yet showed clear friction over religious freedom issues. When China revised its Religious Affairs Regulations in 2018, the state dramatically tightened control over religious activities. As a result, hundreds of Korean missionaries living in China were expelled, and local Christian communities faced severe pressure. Nevertheless, Korean churches maintained clandestine support and exchanges through networks with China's underground churches. This was the practice of the belief that "the Gospel transcends borders"—a solidarity of faith communities that rose above inter-state conflicts.

Our diplomatic relations with Japan throughout the 2010s were a continuous series of conflicts over comfort women, forced labor, and Dokdo territorial disputes. These weren't merely political issues—they affected national sentiment and the practice of believers. Korean churches prayed for peace and reconciliation amid Korea-Japan tensions while adding their voice to demands for historical accountability. However, religious cooperation with Japanese churches notably contracted under government tensions, and civilian-level interfaith reconciliation efforts hit their limits.

With Chistian-majority Countries

With the United States, we maintained our traditional alliance, which extended beyond military and economic ties into Christian networks. Korean-American evangelical churches collaborated in missions, education, and relief work, with theological exchanges flourishing especially among megachurches. Yet conflicts arose over social issues like abortion, homosexuality, and immigration policy. The solidarity between American evangelical circles and Korean conservative Christianity influenced each other not only theologically but politically as well.

Our relationship with Australia was quiet but steady. The missionary alliance forged after the Korean War continued into the 2010s, with Australian churches actively participating in Korean missionary training, local welfare cooperation, and Asian missionary partnerships. Korea and Australia shared welfare models and missionary strategies, jointly grappling with the church's role in the post-Christian era.

Patriotism and Nationalism

Within this diplomatic context, Korean society displayed new dimensions of patriotism and nationalism. Major events like the 2014 Sewol ferry tragedy, the 2016-2017 Park Geun-hye impeachment crisis, and the 2018 inter-Korean summit simultaneously revealed public anger and hope, frustration and solidarity. Conservative Christian rallies with Korean flags combined patriotism with anti-communism and anti-LGBTQ movements under the banner of "prayer for the nation," showing a completely different form of faith practice from the candlelight vigils in the squares. Meanwhile, progressive Christian circles focused on human rights, justice, peaceful unification, and anti-discrimination issues, actively participating in candlelight rallies and social movements. They emphasized public theology as prophetic faith practice and led movements questioning the church's responsibility in society. The nationalism of this period wasn't a single current, but a field where multiple Christian ethics and patriotic discourses clashed within a fractured political landscape.
